Her best products are sugar, rice, soap and salt which she buys by the kilo for 20 MZN and resells at 25 MZN, by the bag for 500 MZN and resells at 600 MZN and by the box for 200 MZN and resells at 275 MZN, as in the region where she resides they live off more agricultural products. She works from 7am to 6pm and has a monthly income of 4,000.00 MZN, of which she manages to save 1,000.00 MZN, as apart from her children, she is also responsible for her grandmother to whom she sends 500 MZN a month.

This is her second loan with Hluvuku and her first with Kiva. Her first loan for 7,000.00 MZN was used to purchase staple goods for resale and she is asking for this second loan of 10,000.00 MZN for the same purpose. She is confident that she will pay off her loan without any problems and will request a new loan to continue building her stall.


Translated from Portuguese by Ines Teles, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and resale of various products

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita G. is a 72 year old mother of eight who has been a member of ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Incorporated) for nine years.  She is applying for a loan to buy a second hand tricycle (a motorcycle with side car) and to repair a fishing boat.  Her previous loans were used to buy a motorized boat used in fishing.   The boat was managed by her son.   

She joined ASHI to fill the spot vacated by her daughter Jocelyn, who died because of a terminal ailment. Rosita’s long membership has really impacted her life and her family’s too.   She has been able to send all her children to college, and all of them are now degree holders.  Four have become seafarers.

The income is shared with the family and supports the education of her grand children, the children of her deceased daughter who she is now helping to raise.

She hopes that in the future, she could save more money to repair their house and to send her grand children to a university.

loans.use: Buy a used motorcycle with side car and repair a fishing boat.

loans.name: Axadbek

texts.ru: Недавно Ахадбеку исполнилось 30 лет.  Ранее он выезжал на заработки в Россию, но постепенно заработка стало меньше и он решил приехать в Таджикистан. На накопленные деньги Ахадбек решил начать свой собственный бизнес. Начал с купли продажи сухофруктов, но потом решил приспособить маленькое помещение у себя дома и завез туда продукты питания. В том районе где он живет нет такого магазина и поэтому его магазин приобрел популярность и постоянных клиентов. Ахадбек женат и у него маленький ребенок. Ахадбек узнал о программе кредитования КИВА и решил подать заявку на займ для расширения своего бизнеса.
texts.en:
Axadbek recently turned 30 years old. He used to take jobs in Russia, but gradually the number of jobs has decreased and he decided to come home to Tajikistan. With the money he saved, Axadbek decided to open his own business. In the beginning he sold dried fruit, but then decided to convert a small room in his house and stocked groceries. There are no stores in the neighborhood where he lives so his store has gained popularity and regular customers. Axadbek is married and has a small child. He learned about Kiva's credit program and decided to submit an application for a loan in order to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand his grocery store

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en: Saratu A. is forty-six years old. She is divorced and has one daughter who is currently independent and working. Saratu sells maize and millet in the local market of Abeka, a town in the Greater Accra region of Ghana. Her major difficulty has to do with funds to support the business. She is requesting this loan to enable her to buy maize and millet in bulk to grow her business and scale up sales. She hopes to increase her savings to pay for the education of her late sister’s children. She is a member of a community group called “Baameyi shei Allah” which literally means unity Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral and assist one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase maize and millet for re-sale

loans.name: Risikatu

texts.en: Risikatu sells provisions, plastics, and drinks. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more provisions, plastics, and drinks to sell. She is a widow with 8 children. She is 62 years old. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, plastics, and drinks to sell

loans.name: Lina

texts.es:
Lina  es socia del Bancomunal Maria Elena Moyano.
Lina es viuda tiene 67 años, tiene 7 hijos, mayores son independientes. 
Lina tuvo un restaurante y creció que lo hizo polleria cuando todo iba bien se enfermo le dio hemiplejia, estuvo mal por varios meses, y cerrar su negocio. compro una moto-car y un carro  lo dio en alquiler, su negocio es de alquiler de taxis y moto-car. Ella administra todo  Vive de las ganancias. 
Desde que esta en Finca, los prestamos han ayudado a invertir ha podido construir su casa ahora la alquila.
Lina necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para bajada de motor de su carro y compra de llantas. 
El sueño de Lina es Viajar a diferentes lugares, para distraerse.
texts.en:
Lina is a member of the communal bank Maria Elena Moyano. She is a widow; is 67; and has 7 children, who are all adults and independent. She had a restaurant which she grew, and she turned it into a poultry shop. Everything was going well when she got sick with hemiplejia. She was sick for several months and closed her business. She bought a motorcycle rickshaw and rented it out. Now her business is renting taxis and motorcycle rickshaws. She manages everything and lives off of the profits. Since she has worked with Finca, her loans have helped her invest and she has been able to build her house, which she now rents out. Lina needs a loan of 1,000 PEN so she can repair her car's engine and buy tires. Lina's dream is to travel.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Lina needs a loan of 1,000 PEN to repair her car's engine and to buy tires

loans.name: Ngea

texts.en: Ngea R., 45, is a grocery seller at a local market in Battambong Province with an income of US$ 3 per day. Together R. and her husband have three children: two of them are students and the oldest child is employed as a builder. Due to the difficulties of family expenses and living,  Ngea R. wants to take out a loan of US$ 1000 to expand the inventory of her grocery store. (Her husband is present in the picture because R. was not available.)

loans.use: buying groceries

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es: Teresa, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Esmeralda”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 39 años y es madre de 01 hijo, que aun dependen de ella.Con la seguridad de tener muy buena clientela, por iniciativa tanto de ella y de su esposo, emprendieron su propio negocio de venta de agregados (arena, piedra)   que son los insumos necesarios para la construcción de casas, edificios que son extraídos de la cantera de los ríos, autorizados y vendidos por la municipalidad del distrito.  En la actualidad, pese al tiempo transcurrido continúa con el mismo negocio, contando con una clientela ya fidelizada que a diario realizan sus pedidos de agregados, donde ella los atiende con el carisma que siempre le ha caracterizado. Con este préstamo de S/. 2,200.00, comprará agregados como: 100 sacos de arena, 10 volquetes de piedras, así implementar su negocio y cumplir con los pedidos de sus clientes.Esta preparada para todo y aun se siente con muchas fuerzas para continuar trabajando y seguir adelante, Teresa de Jesús, agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Teresa is a member of the Esmeralda Microfinance Institute, located in the Tarapoto district of the province and department of San Martín. She is a 39-year-old married mother with one independent son. Certain that she would have a solid client-base, she and her husband took the initiative and started their own construction aggregate business, selling sand and gravel. These materials, which are needed for constructing houses and other buildings, are extracted from the river quarry, authorized and sold by the municipality. She currently has this same business despite all the time that has gone by, and she has faithful customers who buy from her everyday. She attends to them with the charm for which she has always been noted. With this 2,200.00 PEN loan, she will purchase aggregates like: 100 sacks of sand and 10 truckloads of gravel so that she can restock her business and fill her customers’ orders. She is prepared for everything and feels the strong enough to keep working to get ahead. Teresa de Jesús gives thanks to the Manuela Ramos Movement for contributing to the realization of her goals and dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction aggregate

loans.name: Wennelyn

texts.en:
Wennely is a young mother to two kids. She is married to Chito, 27 years old and a rickshaw driver. Even with her young age, she opened her eyes to a much wider perspective in life. She dreams of pulling her family out of poverty. She lives in Antipoly City, Rizal province in the Philippines.

As a woman of hope, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2005. While her husband is engaged with driving a rickshaw, she thinks of a business which can help her husband in earning money. Considering that she has young children, she decided to open a Sari-sari Store (General Store) in their house. The business ran well and her neighbors became her regular customers.

Now on her 6th loan, she is requesting 20,000 pesos as additional capital for her store. The loan will be used to pay for cases of soft drinks, liquors, rice, charcoal and many other groceries for the store.

She is optimistic that with her growing business, she will be able to save for the future of her children, especially the education expenses, and hopeful of expanding her business.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Rona

texts.en:
Mrs. Rona M., 34 years old, married with 1 child and coming from Prk Malipayon, Brgy. Atipuluhan, Bago City, Negros Occidental says that she is very lucky, thankful and proud that she has been part of NWTF-Project Dungganon for over 9 years because it has contributed a lot to improving her standard of living.

Mrs. M. is engaged in running a general store, specifically selling rice products in her local community and nearest town. Her 9th loan amounting to Php 29,500 will be utilized in expanding her business. From this business she earns Php 10,000 per month and it helps a lot in covering the needs of immediate members of her family. She has learned a lot from NWTF-Project Dungganon on how to manage and develop her business which has ultimately improved the life of her family.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria, a 24-year-old woman, is married and the mother of a 6-year-old child. She started her own business selling local beer three years ago. Maria works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 110,000 Tanzania shillings.

Maria is a member of the Mgodi borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. This is Maria's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for local beer. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Maria hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for local beer

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en: Vilma A. is a 37-year-old mother to 6 children. She has been married for 20 years. As the main source of livelihood, farming keeps her family carrying on in life. In her farming experience, harvest depends on how much financing was spent on the farm. She had had a good deal of harvest and also dealt with only a little. She joined CEVI mainly because of its low interest rate. She has applied for Php 6,000, which will be used for farm inputs. This loan will help Vilma produce a good harvest.

loans.use: farm inputs

loans.name: Kiet

texts.en: Kiet D., 32, lives in Phnom Penh. To earn a living, Kiet D. sells various types of meatballs that she buys in bulk on credit from her regular supplier. She typically makes around of $5 USD income a day to help support her family's living expenses. In addition, her husband plants a few crops and is a fisherman.  Kiet D. has five single children, three of whom are working in different occupations. Kiet D. currently needs to pay a lot of money to the owner of the market kiosk which sells her product. To eliminate this fee, Kiet D. would like a loan of $1000 USD to buy her own kiosk in the market.

loans.use: To buy her own kiosk in the market

loans.name: Malolet

texts.en:
Malolet M. is a 32-year-old general store owner who lives in Baseco Compound, Port Area, Manila. Rizalino, her husband, is a carpenter.  Their only child is in grade school.

Malolet owns and manages a general store, which has been in existence for eight years now. She also sells fresh meat at her store. Additionally, she provides water services to a few neighbors. Combined, she makes 50,000 PHP a month. Malolet says perennial rains and flooding hinder the growth of her store but thanks to her perseverance, she will get through it.

In 2004, she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She has seen a lot of economic, as well as spiritual, developments in her life since joining the cooperative.  She has learned from the cooperative the importance of saving for the future. She is now applying for a new loan in the amount of 26,000 PHP as additional capital for the growth of her store. She will re-stock her grocery inventory. She hopes to see her store grow even bigger. 


About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Restock grocery items at her general store

loans.name: Mujeres En Desarrollo 2 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Maximo is a 42-year-old borrower who lives near San Pedro D. Macorís, Dominican Republic. He is the coordinator for his group, Mujeres en Desarrollo (Women in Development), and his story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Specifically, Maximo and his fellow borrowers live in Batey Margarita. Bateyes are small, rural communities built by sugar companies for their field workers. Bateyes are isolated, have no running water, and have unreliable electricity at best. Maximo lives with his wife and four children, the youngest of whom is six years old. This is Maximo’s sixth loan with Esperanza International.

Maximo runs a successful colmado, which is the local version of a small general store. With his loan, he plans to buy foods such as rice, beans, flour, and oil, as well as gasoline and some clothing to sell to his community. He is slowly expanding his business and offering more products to his customers as each new loan comes in. Maximo knows that even though his loans may be small, little by little he is improving the life of his business, his own life, and his family’s lives. Thank you for lending to Maximo and the Mujeres en Desarrollo group!

loans.use: To purchase rice, beans, clothing, and gasoline for resale.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es: Graciela es una mujer  dinámica, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 32 años, es madre de tres menores de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de gaseosas, chupetes, hielos, néctares y también vende productos de belleza por catálogo, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo el cual es profesor. Siempre han salido adelante pese a las dificultades que han pasado. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “De la Amistas II” desde hace siete años. El primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que le permitió invertir en productos de belleza, ahora Graciela necesita un crédito de 1000 soles, que será utilizado para comprar queso al por mayor y luego comercializarlo. La meta de Graciela es llegar a tener una fuente de soda en su casa.
texts.en:
Graciela is a dynamic woman who lives in the city of Pucallpa, Ucayali region. She is 32 years old and the mother of three dependent children.

Graciela sells sodas, lollipops, ice, nectars, as well as beauty products through a catalog. She has the support of her husband, who is a teacher by profession. Despite the difficulties she has faced, she always strives to get ahead. Graciela joined the Communal Bank “De la Amistas II” seven years ago. The first loan she received was in the amount of 300 soles, which she invested in beauty products. She is now requesting a loan of 1000 soles so that she can buy cheese in bulk for later resale. Her goal is to open a soda fountain in her house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cheese to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of maize flour in bulk

loans.name: Kosim

texts.ru: Косим Данияров проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст 40 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Косим более 28 лет работает по своей профессии "учителем". Помимо он более 4 лет занимается сельским хозяйством. Клиент в основном выращивает фрукты, сухофрукты и т.д. Кредит просит для того чтобы посеить новый урожай, т.е. закупить семена и мин. удобрения.
texts.en:
Kosim D. lives in the Shahrituz region. He's forty years old, married and has five children. For more than twenty-eight years he has worked as a teacher. Additionally, he has occupied himself as a farmer for the last four years. In general, he grows fruits, dried fruits, etc. He is asking for a loan in order to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer with which he could plant a new crop.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Anta

texts.fr: Anta S. est une femme de 67 ans, mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle teint une boutique où elle vend diverses denrées alimentaires. Son objectif est de renforcer son activité, d’augmenter son épargne et de mieux prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Anta S. is a 67-year old woman who is married with six children. She has a shop where she sells various foodstuffs. Her objective is to strengthen her business, to increase her savings and to be able to take better care of her family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To keep a shop selling various products

loans.name: Tereza

texts.es:
Tereza, D. 50 años, es una mujer que a lo largo D. su vida ha trabajado mucho por mejorar su calidad D. vida. Vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Enrique, D. 50 años, y lo que más desea es tener una vejez tranquila.
En el mercado Tupac Amaru (mercado importante D. la ciudad D. Juliaca) se encuentra su negocio. Ella venD. D. ropa y su puesto es uno D. los más concurridos, ya que las prendas que venD. las trae D. la ciudad D. Lima, motivo por el cual la ropa que tiene en stock es novedosa y D. muy buena calidad.
Por otro lado, lo que más le gusta D. su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas D. venta, así hace más amenas sus largas jornadas D. trabajo. Lleva 12 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es permanecer todo el día en su puesto en espera D. los clientes.
Con el tiempo, desea ampliar las instalaciones D. su puesto para poder ofrecer mayor comodidad.

Este es el primer préstamo al que acceD. Tereza con MFP y se compromete a ser muy puntual en sus cuotas. En su banco comunal es muy alegre y siempre les da consejos a las demás socias. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más ropa para implementar su puesto.
texts.en:
Tereza is 50 years old and is a woman who has worked hard all her life to improve her quality of life. She lives in her own home with her husband Enrique, also 50, and her greatest wish is to have a peaceful life as she grows older. Her business is located in the Tupac Amaru market (an important market in the city of Juliaca). She sells clothing and her stall is one of the busiest ones because she brings the clothing she sells from Lima. For this reason her stock of clothing is modern and of very good quality. What she likes most about her job is chatting with the neighboring vendors in the market, which makes her long workdays more pleasant. She has been doing this work for 12 years and thinks the hardest part is staying at her stand all day awaiting customers. In time she would like to expand her stall in order to make it more comfortable. This is Tereza's first loan with MFP and she has promised to be on time with her payments. In her Communal Bank she is known as a happy person and she always has advice for other members. With the 1000 Peruvian Soles she will buy more clothing to help grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Amelia's Group

texts.en:
Amelia M. is from the village of San Marcos. She is 32 years old. Amelia is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Amelia is married and has 4 school-aged children. Amelia owns & operates a vegetable growing and selling business. Amelia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Amelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Amelia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Amelia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Daysi

texts.es: En el municipio de Somotillo comarca el puma la señora Daysi C. M., se dedica a la crianza de ganado bobino y porcino junto a su esposo también es empleada de un centro educativo de primaria en donde imparte clases, ella empezó a dedicarse a la crianza de ganado cuando de caso, ella trabaja de 7 a 12 del día en la escuela y por la tarde le colabora a su esposo con las actividades de la finca, solicita el crédito para la compra de dos vacas paridas y aumentar su hato ganadero y  diversificar todos sus ingreso, para ofrecer un mejor bienestar económico a sus tres pequeños hijos
texts.en:
Daysi C. M. raises cattle and pigs in the Somotillo municipality in the town of El Puma. She does this with her husband. She is also employed at an educational center for primary education where she teaches classes. She started raising livestock when she got married. She works from seven until twelve at the school. In the afternoon she works with her husband on the farm. She is asking for a loan to buy two calving cows to increase their herd, to diversify their income, and to give their three small children a better state of economic well-being.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy two calving cows

loans.name: Granito De Oro Group

texts.en:
The Granito de Oro Communal Association belongs to the Germán Busch Focal Centre, located on the outskirts of the city of El Alto. The members of the association are taking out a loan to support their businesses. The members work in a variety of businesses, selling food, cosmetics and artisanal products.

Hilda C. from the Granito de Oro Group, together with her mother-in-law, currently sells food, working Tuesdays, Fridays and Sundays. She used to sell cosmetics but this took up a lot of time which she also needed to look after her family.

With this loan, Hilda intends to set up her own stall selling food in the evenings. Her most popular dish is “silpancho”, a specialty from the Cochabamba region of Bolivia: a large, thin, breaded steak served with a fried egg and on a bed of rice and potato.

Please consider lending to the women of Granito de Oro so that they might grow their businesses.

loans.use: To set up a new food business

loans.name: Cecile

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et mère de 03 enfants, son époux est un mécanicien et ils vivent ensemble dans le quartier d’aguiarkomé qui est un quartier périphérique de Lomé. En 1998 elle a débuté le commerce de produits pharmaceutique, elle s’approvisionne à Accra, ainsi le coût d’achat  lui revient moins chère et elle réalise ainsi de meilleures profits. son stock a baissé, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et  sollicite donc de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 5 cartons de seringue,6 cartons de paracétamol et divers autres produits pharmaceutiques.
texts.en:
This is lady who is married and the mother of three children.  Her husband is a mechanic, and they live together in Aguiarkomé, an outlying district of Lomé.  In 1998, she started a pharmaceuticals business.  She gets her supplies from Accra, so the purchase price is less expensive for her. She realizes better profits in this way.  Her inventory is low.  She would like to stock up again and is therefore requesting a loan from WAGES for buying five boxes of syringes, six boxes of Paracétamol (reduces pain and fever), and other pharmaceutical products.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pharmaceutical products

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 45 years old and married with four children who go to school. She has been running a bakery in Nairobi for five years to earn a living. She bakes her cakes and distributes them locally to retail shops. She was previously selling animal feeds before she ventured into this business. 

She is a member of the Five Star group in Faulu Kenya, which consists of entrepreneurs who are willing and determined to improve their lives. The members of the group meet on a weekly basis to save their money and co-guarantee each other to borrow loans. 

She has requested a loan of 81,700 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to buy a solar panel. She hopes to grow her business and improve her living standards in the future.

loans.use: To buy a solar panel

loans.name: Judith

texts.es:
Judith es socia del Banco Comunal Llamkasum que significa trajeamos en quechua.
Judith es soltera, tiene 39 años y 1 hija, Judith junto a su hermano tienen una tienda en local alquilado en donde vende abarrotes en general, además venden productos de Bimbo y Unión que reparten a las tiendas y market de la ciudad.
Judith necesita un préstamo de 2100 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar.
Judith sueña con tener casa propia, local propio y que su hija sea profesional.
texts.en:
Judith is a memember of the Llamkasum Community Bank. Llamkasum means 'We Clothe' in Quechua. Judith is single, 39 years old, and has a daughter. Judith and her brother have a store in a rented property where they sell groceries as well as Bimbo and Unión products that they distribute to the stores and city market.

Judith needs a loan of 2,100 soles to invest in the purchase of rice and sugar. Judith dreams of having her own home, her own store, and for her daughter to have a professional career.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and sugar

loans.name: Sónia

texts.pt:
Sónia A. M. nasceu na Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, tem 27 anos de idade, casada e  mãe de 1 filho de 12 anos de idade, vai a escola. Fez somente 5ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte dos progenitores. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Saiu de Gaza para Maputo no Distrito de Boane com seus pais ainda muito nova. Tem um negocio próprio ha mais de 5 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento de cerca de 9.000.00mt que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum de vez enquanto na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua amiga que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, barrotes, blocos, ferro e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua casa. O empréstimo anterior foi no valor de 5.000.00mt para a mesma actividade. 
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para conclusão da sua casa e oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Sonia A. M. was born in the province of Gaza in the south of Mozambique. She is 27 years old, married, and has a 12-year-old son who attends school. Sonia only studied through 5th grade, and didn't continue because of her parents’ lack of financial resources. She lives with her family in their own house and doesn’t help support anyone else financially. She left Gaza for the Boane district of Maputo with her parents when she was still quite young. She has owned her own business for more than 5 years. She doesn’t employ any help and has a monthly income of around 9000 Meticais. She uses this income to cover household expenses and occasionally saves some in her bank account as well. Sonia has never taken out a loan with another bank. She found out about Hluvuku [the Kiva Field Partner] through a friend who also works with the institution. This is her 2nd loan, for the amount of 15,000 Meticais. She plans to use this money to buy construction materials (cement, bars, blocks, iron and other items) in order to continue working on the construction of her home. Her earlier loan was for 5000 Meticais and was used for the same purpose. She promises to repay the loan as indicated in order to be eligible for other loans later. In the future she would like to apply for more loans to finish her house and offer her family better living conditions.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement and other items)

loans.name: Tarcila

texts.en:
Tarcila B. is from the village of Brgy Quezon, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old. Tarcila is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Tarcila owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Tarcila has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Tarcila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tarcila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Tarcila is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Tarcila from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items and expand product offering

loans.name: Louie

texts.en:
Louie M., from Gango Ozamiz City, is 30 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Louie owns and operates a business offering transportation services. Engaged in his business for over a year, he earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Louie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 10000 PHP to repair his existing vehicle for better service, he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Ham

texts.en:
Mrs. Ham H. is 56 years old and is a widowed mother devoted to her two children. One is now married and lives separately while the other one is single.

Ham H. stays at home to manage the family housework as well as selling some inventory to the villagers. She sells items such as cooking equipment, soft drinks, snack food, sweets (candies), meat, and some vegetables. She buys her items in bulk on credit from wholesale suppliers and pays when she sells all her products.

Ham H. thinks that it is time to sustain her business’s growth and look for extra revenue, which she proposes to do by increasing her inventory. Due to the fact that she doesn’t have capital to make that possible, she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Tom Khorn Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fourteen members who are made up a village bank loan live in Chuos village in Takeo province. Mrs. Tom K. is a village bank president who was born in 1973, selected by the other members who will use portion of their loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family and she is also a Khmer cake seller while her husband, Mr. Khoeurn Phen, is a pig middleman who is also earned some money to support his family. Since her husband’s business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Tom K. is asking for a loan to buy a mother pig. She is a mother of four children whom all are studying in local public school and they are helping their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy a mother pig

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: La Señora Maria Auxiliadora  tiene 55 años de edad, ella no pudo finalizar sus estudios. Tiene 2 hijos y trabajan de manera independiente, ella brinda los productos de venta de ropa y cosméticos tiene una excelente atención con sus clientes, razón por la cual ella tiene en el negocio más de 5 años y poco a poco a construido su casita y educado a sus hijos. Ella solicita el préstamo para comprar mercadería y de este modo abastecer su negocio. Maria valora y agradece infinitamente el crédito otorgado ya que este le permite crecer con su negocio y mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Maria Auxiliadora is 55 years old; she was unable to complete her education. She has 2 children and is self-employed. She offers clothing and cosmetics for sale and gives excellent service to her customers. For this reason she has been in business for more than 5 years and little by little has built her home and educated her children. She is requesting a loan to buy merchandise and be able to stock up her business. Maria appreciates and is extremely grateful for this loan, which will allow her to grow her business and improve her standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes P. B. e  es una señora de 51  años que vive con su esposo y su hija en un pequeño pueblo llamado Cartagena de Santa Cruz, Guanacaste, esta ciudad   es conocida como la cuna del folklore costarricense, es una planicie de clima muy cálido donde la principal actividad económica es la ganadería y el turismo que se ha desarrollo gracias a su cercanía a las mejores playas del país. 

Doña Mercedes se ha destacado siempre por ser una mujer emprendedora, desde muy chiquita le ayuda a su familia vendiendo helados en los principales parques de la comunidad. Hoy ella tiene su propio negocio, una venta de zapatos a domicilio. Ella compra y vende zapatos casa por casa en su comunidad.
 Asegura que le ha ido bastante bien, pero necesita invertir más para hacer su negocio crecer  y así poder cumplir su sueño de tener su propia zapatería. Es por eso que Doña Mercedes necesita un préstamo de ¢500,000 (quinientos mil colones) para comprar más zapatos, y así aumentar sus ventas y ofrecerles  mayor variedad a sus Clientes

Ella  es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Cartagena  una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer  crédito, y esta muy feliz de que tiene una nueva esperanza de cumplir sus sueños.
texts.en:
Mercedes P. B. is 51 years old. She lives with her husband and her daughter in a small town called Cartagena de Santa Cruz, Guanacaste. This town is known as the cradle of Costa Rican folklore. It is on a very hot plain where the principal economic activities are ranching and tourism, which has developed thanks to the area's proximity to the best beaches in the country. Mercedes has always stood out for being very entrepreneurial. Starting when she was very young, she helped her family selling ice cream in the main parks of the community. Today she has her own business, selling shoes door to door. She buys and sells shoes door to door in her community. She tells us that her business has gone quite well, but she needs to invest more in order for her business to grow and for her to realize her dream of having her own shoe store. For this reason she is requesting a loan of 500,000 (five hundred thousand Colones) to purchase more shoes so she can increase her sales and offer better variety to her customers. Mercedes is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Cartagena, one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan. She is very happy that she has a new opportunity to achieve her dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes to sell

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida S. is the leader of this group. She is 53 years old and married. She has a son who is eleven years old. Her husband is retired. Zubaida grows rice and sunflowers. Her husband helps her with the farming. She started this activity seven years ago with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS. Now, she earns 7,000 KGS monthly from her farming business. She decided to start breeding cattle. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle, which will be the start for her cattle-breeding business. In the future, she is planning to buy a house in Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan.
 
Group members:
Nurzhamal S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 44 years old and married. She has a daughter who is 16 years old. Her daughter goes to school. Her husband works in Russia. She is a farmer. She started farming seven years ago with an initial investment of 7,000 KGS spent on sowing sunflowers. Now, she earns 5,000 KGS monthly. She decided to start breeding cattle. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she plans to build a house.
 
Shazada M. is 50 years old and married. Her husband is retired, and his monthly retirement allowance is 2,500 KGS. Her daughter is 17 and enrolled in an institution of higher education. She farms sunflowers and rice. She started farming ten years ago with an initial investment of 2,000 KGS. Her monthly income is 5,000 KGS. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle and start breeding them. In the future, she is planning to build a house and purchase furniture for it.
 
Aiymkan B. is 62 years old and a widow. She has two sons who are 26 and 24 years old. Her older son works in Russia, and her younger son is a trader. She grows rice and sunflowers. Her younger son helps Aiymkan with the farming work in his free time. Three years ago she started farming with an initial investment of 2,000 KGS. Her current income is 5,000 KGS. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle to start breeding them.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers, as well as society), Planet (remaining environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Joseph Kagwima

texts.en:
Joseph is 49 years old and married to Mary Kagwira, who is a housewife. They have three children. Joseph is a dairy farmer and he supplies milk to the local dairy and other neighbors near him. He has been in the business for about 12 years and has been earning a profit of 20,000 Kenyan shillings a month.

This is his first loan with KADET and he wants to use the loan to buy animal feed. With the profit, he wants to expand his farm and to start a milk-processing plant in the local community. He hopes to create jobs for the youth and see his children through their education.

loans.use: To buy animal feeds

loans.name: Jose De Los Milagros

texts.es:
José tiene 27 años, es soltero y vive junto a su familia en el caserío Cruz Verde del distrito de Motupe, una zona agrícola de la provincia de Lambayeque, se encuentra situado a una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace más de dos años a la crianza y venta de animales menores, cría diversos animales en algunos corrales situados cerca de su vivienda y cuando estos ya han alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo los ofrece en venta a los negociantes de la zona. Estas actividades son las que le permiten sustentar sus gastos personales y apoyar a su familia.

El desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más animales para ampliar su negocio, piensa comprar ganado ovino, caprino y porcino. De este modo planea ampliar su negocio y percibir más ingresos. Para lograr sus clientes ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.

José desea seguir creciendo para mejorar gradualmente su calidad de vida. Las personas que le conocen le consideran una persona tranquila y responsable.
texts.en:
José is 27 years old and single.  He lives with his family in the Cruz Verde settlement in the Motupe district.  It is an agricultural zone located in the Lambayeque province, which is over an hour and 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

For more than two years he has been raising and selling small animals.  He raises different animals in some pens close to his home.  When the animals have reached a good level of development he sells them to the merchants in the area.  These activities allow him to pay for personal expenses and to support his family.

He wishes to expand his business by purchasing more animals.  He plans to buy sheep, goats, and pigs.  This is the way he plans to expand his business and get more income.

In order to achieve this he has requested a loan for 1,500 soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

José wishes to keep growing in order to gradually improve his quality of life.  The people who know him consider him to be a levelheaded and responsible person.

loans.use: To buy animals to raise and sell

loans.name: Shakeela's Group

texts.en:
Shakeela is a resident of Kasur which is a small city located in Punjab and famous for its tanneries industry in Pakistan.  She has lived there in a 2 room brick house with her family for the last 8 years. She is an embroidery expert. She does different kinds of embroidery on clothes by special order. She is very creative in nature and crafts unique embroider designs which attract customers towards her work. Due to her quality work she receives  regular orders every month. 

She is a mother of a daughter who is studying in 5th grade. She is very dedicated and sincere with her family and work and gives the required time and attention to them. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her embroidery business. With the loan, she will buy embroider items such as beads, colored thread and sketches in bulk quantity for her embroidery business. She has been doing this work for the last 10 years and is very confident that this investment will give a good result to her business.  She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her 1st loan application
.  
Note: “In this photo, the group member Rasoolan is showing her bangles selling business”.

loans.use: To buy supplies for an embroidery business

loans.name: Rosa Esther

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Picoaza  se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la rica cultura histórica que encierran sus montañas.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Rosa, ella tiene 45 años de edad, está casada y fruto de esta relación tuvo tres hijos de 20 – 17  y 8 años de edad, todos estudian en Universidad, colegio y escuela. El esposo es albañil.

Se dedica al comercio, vende ropa de todo tipo y su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, aunque también tiene muchos clientes que le encargan sus productos, trabaja todos los días en las mañanas una vez que sus hijos salen a sus estudios, ella recorre la localidad donde ella vive para vender o para que le hagan los pedidos, deja a crédito y cobra semanalmente, nos cuenta que lleva en este negocio como 12 años y que le va bien. Los productos los compra en Guayaquil.

Este crédito lo va a utilizar en comprar más mercadería en especial interiores de damas ya que tiene algunos pedidos.  Lleva 14 ciclos en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por las facilidades que brinda la institución. Su sueño es tener su propio almacén.
texts.en:
The Picoaza cooperative bank meets every fifteen days in the Picoaza parish of the city of Portoviejo.  This area is known as a commercial zone, for its traditional feasts of San Pedro and San Pablo, and for the rich cultural history that its mountain ranges encircle.

This is where we find Rosa, 45 years old, married, and the mother of three children ages 20, 17 and 8.  They are all studying in school or at the university.  Her husband works in construction.

She dedicates herself to commerce, selling all types of clothing door-to-door, although she also has many customers that place orders with her.  She works every morning, after her children have left for school, traveling throughout her locality to sell her products or take orders.  She delivers on credit, and collects every week.  She tells us that she has been in this business for 12 years, and that things are going well.  She purchases her products in Guayaquil.

This loan is for the purchase of more merchandise, especially women’s undergarments, for which she has some orders.  She is in her 14th cycle with the cooperative bank, and she appreciates the assistance provided by the institution.  Her dream is to have her own store.

loans.use: To purchase clothing, especially women's undergarments.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen S., 22, is married and resides with her husband and child in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. 

S. and her husband sell firewood, earning an income of about USD 3.16 per day. S. has to spend USD 79 on food, USD 6 on electricity and water supplies and USD 26 on other necessary expenses every month.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more firewood to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more firewood to sell

loans.name: Virgen Del Paso Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formó gracias a la Señora Elena Benítez quien vive en Itape. Encantadas aceptaron conformar el Comité de Mujeres Rurales nombrando al Comité Virgen del Paso.
 
Las integrantes del comité se dedican a la Artesanía, que es un trabajo que heredaron de sus padres y va pasando de generación en generación.

Confeccionando hermosas prendas de vestir como ser: camisas, manteles, en aopoi, también las integrantes se dedican al comercio, compostura de calzados, empleada domestica.

Con la ayuda que le ofreció la Fundación Paraguaya, este comité logro mejorar sus ingresos y  también mejorar sus condiciones de vida.

A la misma actividad que se dedica la señora Elena presidenta del grupo, de esta forma ella trabaja y vende su artesanía, obteniendo así el ingreso que ayuda a su familia. Solicita el préstamo para la compra de los accesorios que utiliza en la elaboración de sus artesanías como telas hilos entre otros.
texts.en:
This Committee was formed thanks to Elena Benítez Fernández who lives in the city of Itape.  They were very happy to make up the “Comité de Mujeres Rurales,” or Committee of Rural Women, and named it the “Comite Virgen del Paso,” or the Committee of the Virgen of the Pass.

The members of the committee work as artisans, which is a profession that they inherited from their parents and which is passed down from generation to generation.

They make beautiful items of clothing like shirts and blankets in Ao Po’i (a word in the Guarani language meaning finely woven which refers to embroidery and weaving).  The members also work selling, making shoes, and as domestic workers.

With the help offered by the Fundación Paraguaya, this committee was able to improve its income and also better their quality of life.  

Elena, the president of the group, works in the same activity described above.  She is an artisan and sells her crafts to bring in income that helps her family. She is requesting the loan to buy the materials that she uses to make her artisanal products, like fabrics and threads among other things.

loans.use: Purchase of materials used to make artisanal crafts, for example: threads among other things.
